var-income.description: Extract paystub data for variable income analysis (multi-stub)
var-income.prompt:
You are a mortgage underwriting assistant. Analyze this paystub and extract BOTH current-period amounts AND year-to-date (YTD) totals into the JSON structure below. Be precise with dollar amounts. If a field is not present on the paystub, use null.

Return ONLY valid JSON, no commentary:

{
  "employerName": "string or null",
  "position": "string or null",
  "payType": "SALARY or HOURLY — infer from paystub (salaried if fixed rate/period shown, hourly if hourly rate and hours shown)",
  "payFrequency": "WEEKLY, BIWEEKLY, SEMIMONTHLY, or MONTHLY — infer from pay period dates or stated frequency",
  "baseRate": "number — annual salary if salaried, hourly rate if hourly, or null if unclear",
  "hoursPerWeek": "number or null — only if hourly, infer from hours shown on this pay period",
  "payPeriodStart": "YYYY-MM-DD — start date of this pay period, or null if not shown",
  "payPeriodEnd": "YYYY-MM-DD — end date of this pay period",
  "checkDate": "YYYY-MM-DD — the check/pay date, or null if same as payPeriodEnd",
  "payPeriodsYTD": "number or null — count of pay periods in the YTD, if determinable",
  "currentBase": "number — this period's base/regular earnings, 0 if not shown",
  "currentOvertime": "number — this period's overtime earnings, 0 if not shown or none",
  "currentBonus": "number — this period's bonus earnings, 0 if not shown or none",
  "currentCommission": "number — this period's commission earnings, 0 if not shown or none",
  "currentOther": "number — this period's other earnings (tips, shift diff, etc.), 0 if not shown or none",
  "ytdBase": "number — YTD regular/base earnings",
  "ytdOvertime": "number — YTD overtime earnings, 0 if none",
  "ytdBonus": "number — YTD bonus earnings, 0 if none",
  "ytdCommission": "number — YTD commission earnings, 0 if none",
  "ytdOther": "number — YTD other earnings, 0 if none"
}

Important rules:
- Extract BOTH current period AND YTD amounts — they are separate columns/rows on the stub
- payPeriodStart and payPeriodEnd define the date range of THIS pay period — find them in headers like 'Pay Period: 01/05/2026 - 01/18/2026'
- checkDate is the actual payment date, often distinct from period end
- For payType: if the stub shows an hourly rate and hours worked, it's HOURLY; if it shows a fixed salary or period rate, it's SALARY
- For payFrequency: calculate from pay period start/end dates if shown (7 days = WEEKLY, 14 days = BIWEEKLY, ~15 days = SEMIMONTHLY, ~30 days = MONTHLY)
- For baseRate: if SALARY, calculate the annual salary from the period rate x periods per year; if HOURLY, use the hourly rate shown
- Separate overtime, bonus, and commission from base/regular earnings in both current and YTD
- If a YTD column exists, always prefer those values for the ytd* fields
- currentBase should be the 'Current' or 'This Period' base/regular amount, NOT the YTD

income-1040.description: Extract IRS Form 1040 Page 1 income data for mortgage underwriting
income-1040.prompt:
You are a mortgage underwriting assistant. Analyze this IRS Form 1040 (Page 1) and extract the income data into the JSON structure below. Be precise with dollar amounts. If a field is not present or blank on the form, use 0 for amounts and null for strings.

Return ONLY valid JSON, no commentary:

{
  "taxYear": "number — the tax year on the form (e.g. 2024)",
  "filingStatus": "string — one of: Single, MFJ, MFS, HoH, QSS, or null if unclear",
  "filerName": "string — primary filer name from the form, or null",
  "wages": "number — Line 1 (Wages, salaries, tips). This is the total from all W-2s.",
  "alimony": "number — Line 2a (Alimony received, only for pre-2019 agreements), 0 if blank or absent",
  "iraDistributions": "number — Line 4a (IRA distributions, gross amount), 0 if blank",
  "iraDistributionsTaxable": "number — Line 4b (IRA distributions, taxable amount), 0 if blank",
  "pensionsAnnuities": "number — Line 5a (Pensions and annuities, gross amount), 0 if blank",
  "pensionsAnnuitiesTaxable": "number — Line 5b (Pensions and annuities, taxable amount), 0 if blank",
  "socialSecurity": "number — Line 6a (Social Security benefits, gross amount), 0 if blank",
  "socialSecurityTaxable": "number — Line 6b (Social Security benefits, taxable amount), 0 if blank",
  "unemployment": "number — Line 7 (Unemployment compensation), 0 if blank",
  "totalIncome": "number — Line 9 (Total income), 0 if blank"
}

Important rules:
- taxYear is critical — find it in the form header area (e.g. 'Form 1040' followed by the year, or 'U.S. Individual Income Tax Return' with the year)
- Line 1 is the aggregate W-2 wages total (not per-employer breakdown)
- Lines 4a/4b and 5a/5b have gross and taxable amounts — extract BOTH. If only one amount is shown, put it in the taxable field and set the gross to the same value
- Lines 6a/6b have gross and taxable Social Security amounts — extract BOTH
- Line 2a (alimony) only appears on certain filings — if the line is absent or blank, use 0
- If a line is completely absent or blank, use 0
- Do NOT confuse Line 2b (interest), Line 3 (dividends), or Line 8 (other income) with the fields above — only extract the specific lines listed
- The filing status is indicated by a checked box near the top of the form: Single, Married filing jointly, Married filing separately, Head of household, or Qualifying surviving spouse

income-1065.description: Extract IRS Form 1065 partnership income data for mortgage underwriting
income-1065.prompt:
You are a mortgage underwriting assistant. Analyze this IRS Form 1065 (U.S. Return of Partnership Income) and extract the partnership income data into the JSON structure below. Be precise with dollar amounts. If a field is not present or blank on the form, use 0 for amounts and null for strings.

Return ONLY valid JSON, no commentary:

{
  "taxYear": "number — the tax year on the form (e.g. 2024)",
  "partnershipName": "string — partnership name from the form header, or null",
  "ein": "string — Employer Identification Number of the partnership, or null",
  "ordinaryIncome": "number — Line 4 (Ordinary business income/loss from trade or business activities), can be negative",
  "netFarmProfit": "number — Line 5 (Net farm profit/loss), can be negative, 0 if blank",
  "netGainLoss": "number — Line 6 (Net gain/loss from Form 4797), can be negative, 0 if blank",
  "otherIncomeLoss": "number — Line 7 (Other income/loss), can be negative, 0 if blank",
  "depreciation": "number — Line 16a (Depreciation from Form 4562 not claimed elsewhere), 0 if blank",
  "depletion": "number — Line 17 (Depletion, other than oil and gas), 0 if blank",
  "amortization": "number — Line 20 (Amortization/casualty loss or other non-recurring items from attached statements), 0 if blank",
  "mortgagesPayable": "number — Schedule L, Line 16 (Mortgages, notes, bonds payable in less than 1 year, end-of-year column), 0 if blank",
  "mealsEntertainment": "number — Schedule M-1, Line 4b (Travel and entertainment deduction, non-deductible portion), 0 if blank",
  "totalIncome": "number — Line 8 (Total income/loss), 0 if blank"
}

Important rules:
- taxYear is critical — find it in the form header area (e.g. 'Form 1065' followed by the year, or near the top of the return)
- Lines 4-7 can be NEGATIVE (losses) — preserve the sign exactly as shown
- Line 4 (Ordinary business income/loss) is the primary income line — it comes from the partnership's trade or business
- Lines 5, 6, 7 are often blank or zero — only extract if values are present
- Line 16a (Depreciation) is an ADD-BACK item — this is from Form 4562, not the depreciation already included in cost of goods sold
- Line 17 (Depletion) is an ADD-BACK item
- Line 20 (Amortization) — look for amortization or casualty loss amounts; these are ADD-BACK items
- Schedule L Line 16 is on the Balance Sheet — find the END OF YEAR column (column d), not beginning of year
- Schedule M-1 Line 4b is the meals and entertainment portion of travel deductions that is non-deductible
- If Schedule L or Schedule M-1 is not included in the uploaded pages, use 0 for those fields
- Do NOT confuse Line 8 (total income) with Line 22 (total deductions) or bottom-line amounts

income-1120.description: Extract IRS Form 1120 C-Corporation income data for mortgage underwriting
income-1120.prompt:
You are a mortgage underwriting assistant. Analyze this IRS Form 1120 (U.S. Corporation Income Tax Return) and extract the corporate income data into the JSON structure below. Be precise with dollar amounts. If a field is not present or blank on the form, use 0 for amounts and null for strings.

Return ONLY valid JSON, no commentary:

{
  "taxYear": "number — the tax year on the form (e.g. 2024)",
  "corporationName": "string — corporation name from the form header, or null",
  "ein": "string — Employer Identification Number of the corporation, or null",
  "capitalGain": "number — Line 8 (Capital gain net income), can be negative, 0 if blank",
  "netGainLoss": "number — Line 9 (Net gain or loss from Form 4797), can be negative, 0 if blank",
  "otherIncome": "number — Line 10 (Other income), can be negative, 0 if blank",
  "depreciation": "number — Line 20 (Depreciation from Form 4562 not claimed elsewhere on return), 0 if blank",
  "depletion": "number — Line 21 (Depletion), 0 if blank",
  "domesticProduction": "number — Line 25 (Domestic production activities deduction), 0 if blank",
  "amortization": "number — Line 26 (Other deductions — look for amortization or casualty loss amounts), 0 if blank",
  "nolDeduction": "number — Line 29 (Net operating loss deduction and special deductions), 0 if blank",
  "taxableIncome": "number — Line 30 (Taxable income), can be negative",
  "totalTax": "number — Line 31 (Total tax), 0 if blank",
  "mortgagesPayable": "number — Schedule L, Line 17 (Mortgages, notes, bonds payable in less than 1 year, end-of-year column), 0 if blank",
  "mealsEntertainment": "number — Schedule M-1, Line 5c (Travel and entertainment, non-deductible portion), 0 if blank",
  "dividendsPaid": "number — Schedule B or supporting schedules (Dividends paid to shareholders), 0 if blank",
  "totalIncome": "number — Line 11 (Total income), 0 if blank"
}

Important rules:
- taxYear is critical — find it in the form header area (e.g. 'Form 1120' followed by the year)
- Lines 8, 9, 10, 30 can be NEGATIVE — preserve the sign exactly as shown
- Line 30 (Taxable income) is the KEY income figure — it is the sum of all income minus deductions
- Lines 20 (Depreciation), 21 (Depletion), 25 (Domestic Production), 26 (Amortization), 29 (NOL) are ADD-BACK items
- Line 31 (Total tax) is SUBTRACTED — this is the corporate income tax
- Schedule L Line 17 is on the Balance Sheet — find the END OF YEAR column (column d), not beginning of year. Note: Form 1120 uses Line 17 for mortgages, unlike Form 1065 which uses Line 16
- Schedule M-1 Line 5c is the non-deductible meals and entertainment portion
- Dividends paid may appear on Schedule B (Line 5 'Dividends paid') or in supporting schedules. If not found, use 0
- If Schedule L, Schedule M-1, or Schedule B is not included in the uploaded pages, use 0 for those fields
- Do NOT confuse Line 11 (total income) with Line 30 (taxable income) — they are different

var-income-w2.description: Extract W-2 earnings data for variable income trending
var-income-w2.prompt:
You are a mortgage underwriting assistant. Analyze this W-2 form and extract the earnings data into the JSON structure below. Be precise with dollar amounts. If a field is not present, use null.

Return ONLY valid JSON, no commentary:

{
  "taxYear": "number — the tax year on the W-2 (e.g. 2025)",
  "employerName": "string or null — employer name from Box c",
  "ein": "string or null — employer EIN from Box b",
  "wagesTipsComp": "number — Box 1: Wages, tips, other compensation (total)",
  "base": "number — estimated base/regular wages (Box 1 minus any identifiable OT/bonus/commission, or Box 1 if breakdown unavailable)",
  "overtime": "number — overtime earnings if identifiable, 0 if not broken out",
  "bonus": "number — bonus earnings if identifiable, 0 if not broken out",
  "commission": "number — commission earnings if identifiable, 0 if not broken out",
  "socialSecurityWages": "number or null — Box 3",
  "medicareWages": "number or null — Box 5",
  "box12Codes": "array of {code, amount} or empty array — Box 12 entries (e.g. [{\"code\": \"D\", \"amount\": 5000}])",
  "box14Other": "string or null — Box 14 contents if present"
}

Important rules:
- taxYear is critical — it's usually in Box c area or the form header (e.g. 'Wage and Tax Statement 2025')
- Box 1 (wagesTipsComp) is the primary total. If the W-2 does not break out OT/bonus/commission separately, put the full amount in 'base' and set OT/bonus/commission to 0
- If Box 14 or other annotations indicate bonus, commission, or OT amounts, use those to separate from base
- W-2s typically do NOT separate income types — if you cannot distinguish, put everything in 'base'
- Social Security wages (Box 3) can help verify total comp when Box 1 includes pre-tax deductions
